Snapshots with that lineage arenâ€™t eligible for export. The console is vague; the CLI tells you exactly whatâ€™s going on.
âš–ï¸ Console vs CLI: what actually helps âŒ Console only âœ… CLI runbook Feedback Greyed-out button, no reason why Explicit status & fields (StorageType, errors) Actions Trial and error Deterministic flow (restore â†’ snapshot â†’ export) Repeatability Manual steps Scriptable & auditable ğŸ•µï¸â€â™‚ï¸ Fast diagnosis (CLI) Check the snapshot storage type:
aws rds describe-db-snapshots \ --db-snapshot-identifier <SNAPSHOT_ID> \ --query 'DBSnapshots[0].[DBSnapshotIdentifier,Engine,EngineVersion,StorageType,Encrypted,Status]' \ --output table If StorageType = standard, that snapshot wonâ€™t export. ğŸ§­ Architecture at a glance The flow is straightforward: restore snapshot â†’ temporary gp3 instance â†’ new snapshot â†’ export to S3 with an export role trusted by export.rds.amazonaws.com.
This shows:
ğŸ” Where the storage lineage changes (magnetic â†’ gp3)
ğŸ”— How the export service assumes an IAM role to write to S3
ğŸ§° The minimal moving parts (RDS, S3, IAM, optional KMS)
ğŸ“˜ The playbook (no changes to your existing RDS) We do not modify the current DB instance. We restore the snapshot into a temporary SSD-backed instance, create a new snapshot, and export that one. ğŸ§± Restore the snapshot on gp3 (temporary instance) # Vars export REGION=<REGION> export TEMP_DB_ID=<TEMP_DB_ID> export SNAPSHOT_ID=<SNAPSHOT_ID> export SUBNET_GROUP=<DB_SUBNET_GROUP> export SG_ID=<SECURITY_GROUP_ID> aws rds restore-db-instance-from-db-snapshot \ --region $REGION \ --db-instance-identifier $TEMP_DB_ID \ --db-snapshot-identifier $SNAPSHOT_ID \ --storage-type gp3 \ --no-publicly-accessible \ --db-subnet-group-name $SUBNET_GROUP \ --vpc-security-group-ids $SG_ID ğŸ“¸ Create a new snapshot (now SSD-backed) export NEW_SNAPSHOT_ID=${TEMP_DB_ID}-exportable-$(date +%Y%m%d) aws rds create-db-snapshot \ --db-snapshot-identifier $NEW_SNAPSHOT_ID \ --db-instance-identifier $TEMP_DB_ID # Sanity check aws rds describe-db-snapshots \ --db-snapshot-identifier $NEW_SNAPSHOT_ID \ --query 'DBSnapshots[0].[DBSnapshotIdentifier,StorageType,Status]' \ --output table ğŸ§· Export to S3 (the wiring that matters) âœ… Requirements ğŸŒ S3 bucket in the same region as the snapshot
ğŸ¤ Export IAM role trusted by export.rds.amazonaws.com
ğŸ“ Role permissions to write to S3 (PutObject, ListBucket, GetBucketLocation, etc.)
ğŸ”‘ If using KMS, key Enabled and allows the export service
ğŸ›‘ No Organization SCP blocking rds:StartExportTask
ğŸ‘‡ Trust policy (assumed by the export service) { "Version": "2012-10-17", "Statement": [ { "Effect": "Allow", "Principal": { "Service": "export.rds.amazonaws.com" }, "Action": "sts:AssumeRole" } ] } ğŸ“œ Minimal permissions policy (S3 + KMS) { "Version": "2012-10-17", "Statement": [ { "Effect": "Allow", "Action": [ "s3:PutObject*", "s3:AbortMultipartUpload", "s3:ListBucket", "s3:GetBucketLocation", "s3:DeleteObject*" ], "Resource": [ "arn:aws:s3:::<BUCKET>", "arn:aws:s3:::<BUCKET>/*" ] }, { "Effect": "Allow", "Action": [ "kms:CreateGrant", "kms:DescribeKey", "kms:Encrypt", "kms:GenerateDataKey*" ], "Resource": "<KMS_KEY_ARN>" } ] } ğŸ§¾ Bucket policy (explicit allow for the role) { "Version": "2012-10-17", "Statement": [ { "Sid": "AllowRDSExportWrite", "Effect": "Allow", "Principal": { "AWS": "arn:aws:iam::<ACCOUNT_ID>:role/<RDS_EXPORT_ROLE>" }, "Action": [ "s3:PutObject", "s3:AbortMultipartUpload", "s3:ListBucket", "s3:GetBucketLocation" ], "Resource": [ "arn:aws:s3:::<BUCKET>", "arn:aws:s3:::<BUCKET>/*" ] } ] } â–¶ï¸ Start the export aws rds start-export-task \ --export-task-identifier export-$NEW_SNAPSHOT_ID \ --source-arn arn:aws:rds:$REGION:<ACCOUNT_ID>:snapshot:$NEW_SNAPSHOT_ID \ --s3-bucket-name <BUCKET> \ --s3-prefix rds-exports/$NEW_SNAPSHOT_ID/ \ --iam-role-arn arn:aws:iam::<ACCOUNT_ID>:role/<RDS_EXPORT_ROLE> \ --kms-key-id <KMS_KEY_ARN> ğŸ‘€ Observe the run aws rds describe-export-tasks \ --filters Name=export-task-identifier,Values=export-$NEW_SNAPSHOT_ID \ --query 'ExportTasks[0].[Status,ProgressPercentage,S3Bucket,S3Prefix,FailureCause]' \ --output table ğŸ§¯ Troubleshooting (quick triage) ğŸ” AccessDenied â†’ check Organization SCPs, caller permissions, and the export role policy ğŸ§± KMSKeyNotAccessible â†’ key disabled or a deny affecting export.rds.amazonaws.com ğŸ—ºï¸ BucketRegionError â†’ snapshot and bucket must be in the same region ğŸ¤ Shared snapshot â†’ align KMS access/grants cross-account ğŸ’¡ Lessons Learned Donâ€™t rely on the console to explain the â€œwhyâ€ â€” the CLI is your source of truth Prevent this upfront: standardize on gp3 in modules and block standard storage in CI Keep a pre-approved export role per account/region to avoid one-off IAM changes ğŸ™‹â€â™‚ï¸ Need Help With This? Need help maintaining your RDS setup - keeping backups restorable, snapshot governance tight, etc. ?
Weâ€™ve implemented these patterns across multiple AWS accounts and regions â€” repeatable, auditable, and lowâ€‘touch.

Before jumping into the why and how, here’s what we achieved:
âœ… Replaced a single point of failure with AWS-native components
ğŸ’¸ Reduced monthly costs by 70%
ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» No more SSH, servers, or NGINX restarts
ğŸ” Fully managed SSL with ACM
ğŸ› ï¸ Everything codified and versioned via Terraform
All of this â€” without a single EC2 server or NGINX config file. Why we left EC2 + NGINX behind (and how much it saved us) We had a simple goal: redirect traffic for over 70 different domains.
At first, we solved it with what we knew â€” an EC2 instance running NGINX with hardcoded 301 and 302 rules. It workedâ€¦ until it didnâ€™t.
What started as a quick fix became an operational headache:
Any new redirect meant SSH access and manual file editing Restarting NGINX came with downtime risks A single typo could break everything Most importantly: we were maintaining a full server just to handle redirects Eventually, we asked ourselves: isnâ€™t this just a glorified spreadsheet with SSL and uptime issues?
That question led us to redesign the whole setup using ALB, Terraform, ACM, and nothing else.
And it worked â€” spectacularly. ğŸ’° EC2 vs ALB: The Cost of Simplicity âŒ EC2 + NGINX âœ… ALB + Terraform Cost ~$73/mo ~$22.50/mo Access SSH/SSM required No SSH/SSM ever SSL Manual setup Auto SSL (ACM) Maintenance Manual file editing Fully versioned in Terraform Scalability Single point of failure Fully scalable rules Downtime NGINX restarts cause downtime Zero downtime on rule changes Thatâ€™s a ~70% reduction, with zero servers to maintain and full scalability.
ğŸ›  The New Setup: ALB + Terraform + SSL + Logs Once we made the switch, we wanted the entire solution to be automated, secure, and easy to maintain. Hereâ€™s what we built:
ğŸ“Š Visual Overview: How the Flow Works Sometimes it’s easier to understand this type of infrastructure visually. Here’s a high-level diagram that shows how user requests travel through Route 53, the ALB, and how redirect behavior is handled:
This shows:
What happens when someone accesses a random or known domain How Route 53 routes requests to the ALB The difference between traffic arriving on port 80 and port 443 What the ALB does when no matching redirect rule is found (default 404) ğŸ”§ Components Used ALB (Application Load Balancer): Handles all HTTP/HTTPS requests Redirect Listener Rules: Define what gets redirected and where Route 53: Hosted Zones already managed all our domain DNS AWS ACM: For issuing and auto-renewing SSL certificates Access Logs: Enabled and pushed to S3 for auditing Terraform: Used to define everything as code Modules: We used Anton Babenkoâ€™s modules for alb and acm ğŸ” Managing SSL Certificates with ACM We used ACM (AWS Certificate Manager) to request certificates per domain, with auto-renewal enabled. Since we had all domains in Route 53, validation was done automatically via DNS â€” no manual setup needed.
Code:
module "acm" { source = "terraform-aws-modules/acm/aws" version = "~> 4.0" domain_name = "example.com" subject_alternative_names = ["www.example.com"] zone_id = data.aws_route53_zone.main.zone_id validate_certificate = true } ğŸŒ ALB Listener Rules + Redirects We implemented two listeners:
Port 80 (HTTP): Redirects everything to HTTPS
Port 443 (HTTPS): Processes redirect rules (up to 100 max), default action is 404 Code:
module "redirect_alb" { source = "terraform-aws-modules/alb/aws" version = "9.12.0" name = "redirect-alb" load_balancer_type = "application" internal = false vpc_id = aws_vpc.main.id subnets = [aws_subnet.public_a.id, aws_subnet.public_b.id] access_logs = { bucket = aws_s3_bucket.alb_logs.bucket enabled = true prefix = "alb-access" } create_security_group = true security_group_ingress_rules = { http = { from_port = 80 to_port = 80 ip_protocol = "tcp" cidr_blocks = ["0.0.0.0/0"] } https = { from_port = 443 to_port = 443 ip_protocol = "tcp" cidr_blocks = ["0.0.0.0/0"] } } http_listeners = [ { port = 80 protocol = "HTTP" action = { type = "redirect" redirect = { port = "443" protocol = "HTTPS" status_code = "HTTP_301" } } } ] https_listeners = [ { port = 443 protocol = "HTTPS" certificate_arn = module.acm.certificate_arn rules = [ { priority = 10 actions = [{ type = "redirect" redirect = { host = "www.example.com" status_code = "HTTP_301" protocol = "HTTPS" } }] conditions = [{ host_header = { values = ["old-domain.com"] } }] }, { priority = 20 actions = [{ type = "redirect" redirect = { host = "www.blog.example.com" path = "/blog" status_code = "HTTP_301" protocol = "HTTPS" } }] conditions = [{ host_header = { values = ["legacy-blog.net"] } }] } ] default_action = { type = "fixed-response" fixed_response = { content_type = "text/plain" message_body = "Not Found" status_code = "404" } } } ] } âœ¨ Why This Worked for Us âœ… Fully serverless â€” no EC2 to maintain
âœ… ~70% cost savings
âœ… All redirects are version-controlled in Terraform
âœ… SSL certificates managed automatically (with renewals) via ACM
âœ… Access logs enabled for auditing
âœ… Default rule returns 404 to avoid exposing internal details
âœ… Port 80 cleanly redirects to HTTPS (443)
âœ… Ready to integrate with WAF or CloudWatch in the future
âœ… Everything is Infrastructure-as-Code, ready for CI/CD pipelines
âŒ What We Didn’t Use (And Why) Lambda@Edge â€“ great for complex logic at scale, but overkill for simple 301s. CloudFront Functions â€“ less Terraform support, more limits. S3 Static Hosting â€“ no built-in SSL unless fronted by CloudFront. In the end, simplicity won. ALB covered 100% of our use case â€” no Lambda, no CloudFront needed.
ğŸ“Œ Scaling Tip AWS ALB supports up to 100 listener rules per listener.
If you need more, consider:
â€¢ ğŸ§© Use multiple listeners (e.g., different ports or multiple ALBs)
â€¢ ğŸš€ Move to CloudFront Functions or Lambda@Edge for large-scale redirects
â€¢ ğŸ—‚ï¸ Group redirects using wildcard domains or path patterns
Plan your redirect strategy early to avoid scaling bottlenecks later.
ğŸ’¡ Lessons Learned Keep infrastructure as simple as the problem requires â€” NGINX was overkill for redirects. ALB rules are powerful, but donâ€™t scale infinitely. Plan limits early. Terraform made experimentation and rollback safe and auditable. Relying on managed services like ACM for SSL removed 90% of the ops burden. In short, we turned a fragile EC2 setup into a robust serverless system â€” saving money, effort, and future headaches.
ğŸ™‹â€â™‚ï¸ Need Help With This? Considering a similar migration or want to simplify your redirect setup?
We’ve migrated this same pattern across multiple AWS accounts â€” and the ops team never looked back.
ğŸ’¬ Letâ€™s chat on LinkedIn â€” happy to help or exchange ideas.
